reviews: The pathetic exasperated servant struggling to keep up with the energetic madame is one of the most relatable characters in cinema
When I grow up I want to be just like Madame. However, as a man, I’m more akin to her weak ass manservant.

As tame as this film appears to us today, consider this example: Of the 21 sports in the 1908 Olympics, women were only allowed to participate in tennis, golf, sailing, archery, and figure skating. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participation_of_women_in_the_Olympics#Sports

A quirky French Short that follows the exploits of an unbelievably energetic/athletic woman around her locales in Paris, she was truly a force to be reckoned with.Viewed on Blu Ray (Cinema's First Nasty Women) at home in BNE.

One perfect moment: When Michael and Kay discover Vito’s been shot, his immediate reaction is to race to a phone booth and call home to check on his father. Until this point in the movie, Michael insists he wants no part of his father’s business. But when he reads the newspaper headlines about the assassination attempt, something changes in his face. And then he goes to the phone booth and slams the door on Kay so she can’t overhear the…

The story of the Corleone Family. A close-knit Italian household where the Don knows best. From lavish weddings to ceremonial baptisms, the Corleone's live the American Dream; one cannoli at a time.I had never seen The Godfather until today. I grew up more Tony Montana than Michael Corleone. I liked my gangsters snorting piles and piles of cocaine, and saying hello to their little friend. Later on, I discovered Italian Gangsta EuroTrash Mob Movies and Japanese Yakuza flicks. In…

This was my first viewing ever of The Godfather. I'm sorry everyone. Forgive me. This is the most overrated film I've ever seen to date. However, the acting was outstanding. I loved Marlon Brando in particular. It really frustrates me that I wasn't crazy about this.

I just don't like it, and before you rip my head off and scream endlessly in my dead ear about how amazing this movie is, let me ask you this: Have you ever been in church and the minister up front is droning on and on in a monotone fashion, talking about Biblical side character people and stories that you have absolutely no interest in because they don't relate to you at all. You're looking for anything to attract your…

Maybe it's because I recently watched Part 3 but this viewing the entire thing felt so much more tragic. I mean, sure, Michael becomes a cool mob boss who crushes his enemies but he dooms himself to an existence where he's going to lose everyone close to him. Anyway this movie rules. Every scene is great, every role perfectly cast. Great work, Francis.

This may not be your ordinary family, but they provide enough thrills, laughs, and yes heart, that this sorely needed beacon of hope is exactly what we need right now. The real "offer we can't refuse" is that we all deserve empathy and kindness, which may be the most "Sicilian" message of all in these times.

I hope everyone had a wonderful Thanksgiving!It doesn't get any better than this folks. Every Thanksgiving I watch four films that revolve around the life of the mafia, gangsters, that sort of thing. No matter if I throw in a new film or not, the first two Godfather films are always cemented in my marathon. Simply put, The Godfather is perfect. No film, except it's sequel, has come close to the level of cinematic nirvana that Coppola's work achieves.…

100"In looking at The Godfather as a whole, I simply fall into its rhythms and then three hours pass by, waking up as if in a stupor. It has the immense capacity of feeling as if this stretch of continuity is liquid – flowing by like a river. And yet, The Godfather is a section of a life lived, a rise and a fall, and its ultimate accomplishment is condensing it into an easy-going popular entertainment that still shocks…

This has a reputation for being very good, and it is. They really nailed this one. Congratulations to everyone involved - you are now one of the immortals.You’ve got Brando’s highly stylized, almost gargoyle-like performance, and then you’ve got Pacino’s simmering, internalized performance right next to it, and they fit together perfectly. How did they do it? Folks, it’s called “movie magic.”

When you rewatch something at this level of perfection, you realize how far it is from just a film, it carries legacies, transcends the art of cinema, and becomes a phenomenon with an absurd cultural impact. Francis Ford Coppola is a genius; he created an icon of modern narrative and carried the movement of the new Hollywood as no one could have done. Through a complex tapestry of power, loyalty and morality, the film takes us on a deep dive…

I know people love this movie, but I am very close to hating it.This was my 2nd time watching the film to completion and I think I should get a medal for it. Three long hours of boredom, no characters I can connect with or care about, and a plot that offers the occasional interesting moment but is mostly just people mumbling about how they want to kill other people. If I'm going to spend this much time invested…
Its the godfather, end of review.

Primeiro, parece um festival de grandes curtas metragens, um filme bom depois do outro, “O Casamento”, “A Proposta”, “O Hospital”, “A Siciliana”. Todos filmes belos e verdadeiros, como numa antologia de contos que vão surtindo um efeito cumulativo dramático até que percebe-se que estão todos presos uns nos outros e que a história toda dos Corleone forma uma árvore grande e frondosa onde o tronco termina sendo Michael, que parecia ser só um galho frágil. A primeira vez que eu vi esse filme eu tinha 15 anos, foi na TV. Apple iTunes/Dolby Vision 4K (imagem bela de filme).
